message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: UAV-Assisted Data Collection for Internet of Things: A Survey
Paper Abstract: Thanks to the advantages of flexible deployment and high mobility, unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) have been widely applied in the areas of disaster management, agricultural plant protection, environment monitoring, and so on. With the development of UAV and sensor technologies, UAV-assisted data collection for the Internet of Things (IoT) has attracted increasing attention. In this article, the scenarios and key technologies of UAV-assisted data collection are comprehensively reviewed. First, we present the system model, including the network model and the mathematical model of UAV-assisted data collection for IoT. Then, we review the key technologies, including clustering of sensors, UAV data collection mode as well as joint path planning and resource allocation. Finally, the open problems are discussed from the perspectives of efficient multiple access as well as joint sensing and data collection. This article hopefully provides some guidelines and insights for researchers in the area of UAV-assisted data collection for IoT.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about disaster management:

## Definition and Overview

Disaster management (also called emergency management or emergency preparedness) is a science and a system charged with creating the framework within which communities reduce vulnerability to hazards and cope with disasters.(no content)It involves the organization and management of resources and responsibilities for dealing with humanitarian aspects of emergencies—preparedness, response, mitigation, and recovery—with the aim of reducing harmful effects of all hazards and disasters.

## Key Phases

Emergency management consists of five phases: prevention, mitigation, preparedness, response and recovery. Each phase plays an important role:

- **Prevention & Mitigation**: Disaster mitigation measures eliminate or reduce impacts and risks of hazards through proactive measures taken before an emergency or disaster occurs.

- **Preparedness**: Preparedness focuses on preparing equipment and procedures for use when a disaster occurs, which can be used to reduce vulnerability to disaster, mitigate impacts, or respond more efficiently.

- **Response & Recovery**: The management of disasters requires some combination of activity from individuals and households, organizations, local, and/or higher levels of government.

## Objectives

The outcome of emergency management is to prevent disasters and where this is not possible, to reduce their harmful impacts.

Disaster management is essential for protecting communities and minimizing loss of life and property when disasters occur.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about the Internet of Things:

## Definition and Overview

The IoT encompasses electronics, communication, and computer science engineering.(no content)"The Internet of Things, or IoT, is the integration of people, processes, and technology with connectable devices and sensors to enable remote monitoring, status, manipulation, and evaluation of trends of such devices."

## History

The term "Internet of things" was coined independently by Kevin Ashton of Procter & Gamble, later of Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Auto-ID Center, in 1999.(no content)Cisco Systems estimated that the IoT was "born" between 2008 and 2009, with the things/people ratio growing from 0.08 in 2003 to 1.84 in 2010.

## Key Characteristics

The primary defining characteristic of the Internet of things has been considered its ability to embed short-range mobile transceivers in various gadgets and daily necessities, enabling new forms of communication between people and things, as well as between things themselves.

## Applications

The extensive set of applications for IoT devices is often divided into consumer, commercial, industrial, and infrastructure spaces.(no content)A growing portion of IoT devices is created for consumer use, including connected vehicles, home automation, wearable technology, connected health, and appliances with remote monitoring capabilities.

The Internet of Things continues to expand across various sectors, from everyday consumer devices to specialized industrial and military applications.

Links: [{"title":"Category:Wireless sensor network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Wireless_sensor_network"},{"title":"Wireless sensor network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wireless_sensor_network"},{"title":"Mobile wireless sensor network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_wireless_sensor_network"},{"title":"List of wireless sensor nodes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_wireless_sensor_nodes"},{"title":"Virtual sensor network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_sensor_network"},{"title":"Visual sensor network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_sensor_network"},{"title":"Wireless ad hoc network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wireless_ad_hoc_network"},{"title":"Stochastic geometry models of wireless networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_geometry_models_of_wireless_networks"},{"title":"Zigbee - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zigbee"},{"title":"ANT (network) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ANT_(network)"}]

## Wireless Sensor Network

Here's an overview of wireless sensor networks based on the search results:

### Definition and Purpose

Wireless sensor networks (WSNs) are networks of spatially dispersed and dedicated sensors that monitor and record the physical conditions of the environment and forward the collected data to a central location.(no content)WSN is an emerging class of systems made possible by cheap hardware, advanced programming tools, complex algorithms, long lasting power sources and energy efficient radio interfaces.

### Capabilities and Measurements

WSNs can measure environmental conditions such as temperature, sound, pollution levels, humidity and wind.(no content)Modern networks are bi-directional, both collecting data and enabling control of sensor activity.

### Network Structure

A WSN is built of "nodes" – from a few to hundreds or thousands, where each node is connected to other sensors. Each such node typically has several parts: a radio transceiver with an internal antenna or connection to an external antenna, a microcontroller, an electronic circuit for interfacing with the sensors and an energy source, usually a battery or an embedded form of energy harvesting.

### Applications

The development of these networks was motivated by military applications such as battlefield surveillance. Such networks are used in industrial and consumer applications, such as industrial process monitoring and control and machine health monitoring and agriculture.(no content)Wireless sensor networks have been used to monitor various species and habitats, beginning with the Great Duck Island Deployment, including marmots, cane toads in Australia and zebras in Kenya.

## Wireless Sensor Network

Here's an overview of wireless sensor networks based on the search results:

### Definition and Purpose

Wireless sensor networks (WSNs) are networks of spatially dispersed and dedicated sensors that monitor and record the physical conditions of the environment and forward the collected data to a central location.(no content)WSN is an emerging class of systems made possible by cheap hardware, advanced programming tools, complex algorithms, long lasting power sources and energy efficient radio interfaces.

### Capabilities and Measurements

WSNs can measure environmental conditions such as temperature, sound, pollution levels, humidity and wind.(no content)Modern networks are bi-directional, both collecting data and enabling control of sensor activity.

### Network Structure

A WSN is built of "nodes" – from a few to hundreds or thousands, where each node is connected to other sensors. Each such node typically has several parts: a radio transceiver with an internal antenna or connection to an external antenna, a microcontroller, an electronic circuit for interfacing with the sensors and an energy source, usually a battery or an embedded form of energy harvesting.

### Applications

The development of these networks was motivated by military applications such as battlefield surveillance. Such networks are used in industrial and consumer applications, such as industrial process monitoring and control and machine health monitoring and agriculture.(no content)Wireless sensor networks have been used to monitor various species and habitats, beginning with the Great Duck Island Deployment, including marmots, cane toads in Australia and zebras in Kenya.

Here are the search results for "Data collection":

## Definition
Data collection or data gathering is the process of gathering and measuring information on targeted variables in an established system, which then enables one to answer relevant questions and evaluate outcomes.(no content)Data collection is a research component in all study fields, including physical and social sciences, humanities, and business.

## Purpose and Importance
The goal for all data collection is to capture evidence that allows data analysis to lead to the formulation of credible answers to the questions that have been posed.(no content)Accurate data collection is essential to many business processes, to the enforcement of many government regulations, and to maintaining the integrity of scientific research.

## Key Methods
In research of human subjects, a survey is a list of questions aimed for extracting specific data from a particular group of people and surveys may be conducted by phone, mail, via the internet, and also in person in public spaces.(no content)Mobile data collection or mobile surveys is an increasingly popular method of data collection, with over 50% of surveys today being opened on mobile devices.

## Technical Systems
A data collection system (DCS) is a computer application that facilitates the process of data collection, allowing specific, structured information to be gathered in a systematic fashion, subsequently enabling data analysis to be performed on the information, typically displaying a form that accepts data input from a user and then validates that input prior to committing the data to persistent storage such as a database.

## Search Results for "Resource allocation"

Here's what the web search found about resource allocation:

### Definition and Scope

In economics, resource allocation is the assignment of available resources to various uses.(no content)Resources can be allocated by various means, such as markets, or planning.

### Key Applications

**Economics and Strategic Planning:**
In strategic planning, resource allocation is a plan for using available resources to achieve goals, and it is the process of allocating scarce resources among the various projects or business units.

**Computing:**
In computing, resource allocation is the process by which a computing system aims to meet the hardware requirements of an application, and computing, networking and energy resources must be optimised taking into account hardware, performance and environmental restrictions.

**Organizational Management:**
In organizational studies, resource management is the efficient and effective development of an organization's resources when they are needed, including financial resources, inventory, human skills, production resources, or information technology and natural resources.

### Approaches to Resource Allocation

Resources can be allocated using a manual approach, an algorithmic approach, or a combination of both.

The search results reveal that resource allocation is a fundamental concept with diverse applications across economics, computing, project management, and organizational planning, with various sophisticated methods and fairness criteria developed for different contexts.

Links: [{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"History of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"Unmanned combat aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_combat_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicles in the United States military - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicles_in_the_United_States_military"},{"title":"412th Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Regiment (Ukraine) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/412th_Unmanned_Aerial_Vehicle_Regiment_(Ukraine)"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicle applications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicle_applications"},{"title":"Uncrewed vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_vehicle"},{"title":"Category:Unmanned aerial vehicle manufacturers of the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Unmanned_aerial_vehicle_manufacturers_of_the_United_States"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicle-related incidents - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicle-related_incidents"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about unmanned aerial vehicles:

## Definition

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.

## History

The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, with Austrian forces besieging Venice attempting to launch some 200 incendiary balloons at the besieged city.(no content)The Spanish engineer Leonardo Torres Quevedo introduced a radio-based control-system called the Telekino at the Paris Academy of Science in 1903, as a way of testing airships without risking human life.(no content)In 2006, the United States Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) allowed the usage of unmanned aerial vehicles inside civilian airspace with specific regulations, laying out legal groundwork for consumer drone usage inside the United States.(no content)In 2013, DJI released the first model of the Phantom drone, DJI's fully assembled drone model. Priced at $629, Phantom was an entry-level drone, featuring much more user-friendly experiences than other drones on the market at the time. The DJI Phantom was considered one of the most influential consumer drone products ever made.

## Applications

Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications. These include aerial crop surveys, aerial photography, search and rescue, inspection of power lines and pipelines, inspections for home insurance, counting wildlife, delivering medical supplies to otherwise inaccessible regions, and detection of illegal hunting.

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.

## History

The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, with Austrian forces besieging Venice attempting to launch some 200 incendiary balloons at the besieged city.(no content)The Spanish engineer Leonardo Torres Quevedo introduced a radio-based control-system called the Telekino at the Paris Academy of Science in 1903, as a way of testing airships without risking human life.(no content)In 2006, the United States Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) allowed the usage of unmanned aerial vehicles inside civilian airspace with specific regulations, laying out legal groundwork for consumer drone usage inside the United States.(no content)In 2013, DJI released the first model of the Phantom drone, DJI's fully assembled drone model. Priced at $629, Phantom was an entry-level drone, featuring much more user-friendly experiences than other drones on the market at the time. The DJI Phantom was considered one of the most influential consumer drone products ever made.

## Applications

Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications. These include aerial crop surveys, aerial photography, search and rescue, inspection of power lines and pipelines, inspections for home insurance, counting wildlife, delivering medical supplies to otherwise inaccessible regions, and detection of illegal hunting.

Links: [{"title":"Environmental monitoring - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_monitoring"},{"title":"Environmental Monitoring and Assessment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_Monitoring_and_Assessment"},{"title":"Rover Environmental Monitoring Station - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rover_Environmental_Monitoring_Station"},{"title":"Continuous emissions monitoring system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_emissions_monitoring_system"},{"title":"Biomonitoring - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biomonitoring"},{"title":"World Conservation Monitoring Centre - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Conservation_Monitoring_Centre"},{"title":"Environmental compliance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_compliance"},{"title":"Acid–base titration - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acid–base_titration#:~:text=Acid–base titration allows for,ensuring compliance with environmental regulations."},{"title":"Air quality index - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_quality_index"},{"title":"Federal Service for Hydrometeorology and Environmental Monitoring - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Service_for_Hydrometeorology_and_Environmental_Monitoring"}]

Here are the results for the "Environmental monitoring" web search:

## Overview

Environmental monitoring is the scope of processes and activities that are done to characterize and describe the state of the environment.(no content)It is used in the preparation of environmental impact assessments, and in many circumstances in which human activities may cause harmful effects on the environment.

## Key Areas of Environmental Monitoring

**Air Quality Monitoring**
With the evolution of new chemicals and industrial processes has come the introduction or elevation of pollutants in the atmosphere, as well as environmental research and regulations, increasing the demand for air quality monitoring.(no content)Specialized observation equipment and tools are required to establish air pollutant concentrations, including sensor networks, geographic information system (GIS) models, and the Sensor Observation Service (SOS), a web service for querying real-time sensor data.

**Soil Monitoring**
Soil monitoring involves the collection and/or analysis of soil and its associated quality, constituents, and physical status to determine or guarantee its fitness for use.(no content)Soil monitoring helps characterize threats and other potential risks to the soil, surrounding environments, animal health, and human health.

**Biomonitoring**
Biomonitoring involves the use of organisms to assess environmental contamination, such as of surrounding air or water.(no content)Biomonitoring measures the internal dose of a toxicant within the body rather than its concentration outside the body, with the advantage that it confirms whether not only exposure but uptake has actually occurred.

These search results provide comprehensive information about the definition, methods, and various applications of environmental monitoring across different environmental compartments.

Web search results for query: "Clustering algorithm"

Links: [{"title":"Cluster analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cluster_analysis"},{"title":"k-means clustering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K-means_clustering"},{"title":"Automatic clustering algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automatic_clustering_algorithms"},{"title":"HCS clustering algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HCS_clustering_algorithm"},{"title":"Hierarchical clustering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hierarchical_clustering"},{"title":"Consensus clustering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_clustering"},{"title":"DBSCAN - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DBSCAN"},{"title":"Biclustering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biclustering"},{"title":"Fuzzy clustering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_clustering"},{"title":"Data stream clustering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_stream_clustering"}]

Based on the web search results, here's a comprehensive overview of clustering algorithms:

## Overview

Cluster analysis refers to a family of algorithms and tasks rather than one specific algorithm, and can be achieved by various algorithms that differ significantly in their understanding of what constitutes a cluster and how to efficiently find them.

## Main Cluster Models

Popular notions of clusters include groups with small distances between cluster members, dense areas of the data space, intervals or particular statistical distributions.

The primary cluster models include:

- **Centroid-based**: The k-means algorithm represents each cluster by a single mean vector.
- **Connectivity-based**: Hierarchical clustering builds models based on distance connectivity.
- **Distribution models**: Clusters are modeled using statistical distributions, such as multivariate normal distributions used by the expectation-maximization algorithm.
- **Density-based**: DBSCAN groups together points that are closely packed (points with many nearby neighbors), and marks as outliers points that lie alone in low-density regions.

## Popular Algorithms

**K-means**: K-means clustering is a method of vector quantization that aims to partition n observations into k clusters in which each observation belongs to the cluster with the nearest mean.

**Hierarchical Clustering**: Agglomerative clustering, often referred to as a "bottom-up" approach, begins with each data point as an individual cluster, and at each step, the algorithm merges the two most similar clusters based on a chosen distance metric.

**DBSCAN**: DBSCAN is one of the most commonly used and cited clustering algorithms.

**Fuzzy Clustering**: Fuzzy clustering (also referred to as soft clustering or soft k-means) is a form of clustering in which each data point can belong to more than one cluster.

Web search results for query: "Multiple access channel"

Links: [{"title":"Channel access method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Channel_access_method"},{"title":"Frequency-division multiple access - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frequency-division_multiple_access"},{"title":"Code-division multiple access - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Code-division_multiple_access"},{"title":"Multiple-channel architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiple-channel_architecture"},{"title":"Time-division multiple access - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-division_multiple_access"},{"title":"Multi-user MIMO - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-user_MIMO"},{"title":"Medium access control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medium_access_control"},{"title":"Orthogonal frequency-division multiple access - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orthogonal_frequency-division_multiple_access"},{"title":"Orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orthogonal_frequency-division_multiplexing"},{"title":"Carrier-sense multiple access with collision avoidance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carrier-sense_multiple_access_with_collision_avoidance"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about multiple access channels:

## Definition

A multiple access method (or channel access method) allows more than two terminals connected to the same transmission medium to transmit over it and to share its capacity.(no content)A channel access method is based on multiplexing, which allows several data streams or signals to share the same communication channel or transmission medium.

## Common Applications

Examples of shared physical media are wireless networks, bus networks, ring networks and point-to-point links operating in half-duplex mode.

## Main Types of Multiple Access Schemes

Five principal types of multiple-access schemes include FDMA, TDMA, CDMA, SDMA, and random access.

### Key Schemes:

1. **FDMA (Frequency-Division Multiple Access)**: FDMA is the most standard analog system, based on frequency-division multiplexing, which provides different frequency bands to different data streams. The frequency bands are allocated to different nodes or devices.

2. **TDMA (Time-Division Multiple Access)**: TDMA is a channel access method for shared-medium networks that allows several users to share the same frequency channel by dividing the signal into different time slots.

3. **CDMA (Code-Division Multiple Access)**: CDMA is an example of multiple access where several transmitters can send information simultaneously over a single communication channel, allowing several users to share a band of frequencies.

4. **OFDMA (Orthogonal Frequency-Division Multiple Access)**: OFDMA is a multi-user version of orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing. Multiple access is achieved by assigning subsets of subcarriers to individual users, allowing simultaneous low-data-rate transmission from several users.

## Control Mechanisms

A channel access method may be part of the multiple access protocol and control mechanism, also known as medium access control (MAC), which deals with issues such as addressing, assigning multiplex channels to different users and avoiding collisions.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about multiple access channels:

## Definition

A multiple access method (or channel access method) allows more than two terminals connected to the same transmission medium to transmit over it and to share its capacity.(no content)A channel access method is based on multiplexing, which allows several data streams or signals to share the same communication channel or transmission medium.

## Common Applications

Examples of shared physical media are wireless networks, bus networks, ring networks and point-to-point links operating in half-duplex mode.

## Main Types of Multiple Access Schemes

Five principal types of multiple-access schemes include FDMA, TDMA, CDMA, SDMA, and random access.

### Key Schemes:

1. **FDMA (Frequency-Division Multiple Access)**: FDMA is the most standard analog system, based on frequency-division multiplexing, which provides different frequency bands to different data streams. The frequency bands are allocated to different nodes or devices.

2. **TDMA (Time-Division Multiple Access)**: TDMA is a channel access method for shared-medium networks that allows several users to share the same frequency channel by dividing the signal into different time slots.

3. **CDMA (Code-Division Multiple Access)**: CDMA is an example of multiple access where several transmitters can send information simultaneously over a single communication channel, allowing several users to share a band of frequencies.

4. **OFDMA (Orthogonal Frequency-Division Multiple Access)**: OFDMA is a multi-user version of orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing. Multiple access is achieved by assigning subsets of subcarriers to individual users, allowing simultaneous low-data-rate transmission from several users.

## Control Mechanisms

A channel access method may be part of the multiple access protocol and control mechanism, also known as medium access control (MAC), which deals with issues such as addressing, assigning multiplex channels to different users and avoiding collisions.

Web search results for query: "Path planning robotics"

Links: [{"title":"Motion planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning"},{"title":"Real-time path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_path_planning"},{"title":"Probabilistic roadmap - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probabilistic_roadmap"},{"title":"Any-angle path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Any-angle_path_planning"},{"title":"Robotic mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_mapping"},{"title":"Robot navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_navigation"},{"title":"Multi-agent pathfinding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_pathfinding"},{"title":"OMPL - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OMPL"},{"title":"Navigation function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navigation_function"},{"title":"Pathfinding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pathfinding"}]

I've found comprehensive information about path planning in robotics. Here's what the search results reveal:

## Overview

A basic motion planning problem is to compute a continuous path that connects a start configuration and a goal configuration, while avoiding collision with known obstacles.(no content)Path planning is an important issue as it allows a robot to get from point A to point B.

## Key Concepts

Path planning requires the determination of the robot's current position and a position of a goal location, both within the same frame of reference or coordinates.(no content)Real-Time Path Planning consists of motion planning methods that can adapt to real time changes in the environment, including everything from primitive algorithms that stop a robot when it approaches an obstacle to more complex algorithms that continuously takes in information from the surroundings and creates a plan to avoid obstacles.

## Main Algorithms and Approaches

Several major algorithmic families are used:

- **Sampling-based algorithms**: Sampling-based algorithms avoid the problem of local minima, and solve many problems quite quickly. They are unable to determine that no path exists, but they have a probability of failure that decreases to zero as more time is spent.

- **Grid-based algorithms**: Grid-based approaches discretize the set of actions, and search algorithms (like A*) are used to find a path from the start to the goal.

- **Probabilistic roadmap method**: The probabilistic roadmap planner is a motion planning algorithm in robotics, which solves the problem of determining a path between a starting configuration of the robot and a goal configuration while avoiding collisions.

- **Any-angle path planning**: Any-angle path planning algorithms search for a Euclidean shortest path between two points on a grid map while allowing the turns in the path to have any angle.

## Applications

Motion planning has several robotics applications, such as autonomy, automation, and robot design in CAD software, as well as applications in other fields, such as animating digital characters, video game, architectural design, robotic surgery, and the study of biological molecules.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
